title: Europe Today: EU foreign ministers discuss fresh sanctions on Iran
content: Tune in to Euronews' new flagship morning programme, Europe Today, at 8 am Brussels time. In just 15 minutes, we bring you up to speed on the biggest news of the day.

title: The AI brain drain: Why Europe can’t keep the talent it trains
content: Europe is seeing its AI experts move abroad. Even with strong universities and top research, the EU has a hard time turning these advantages into global leadership in AI.

title: Mercosur, India and the EU: Trade ambitions meet political resistance in The Ring
content: In this week’s episode of The Ring, MEPs Warborn (EPP) and Mullooly (Renew Europe) engage in a heated debate over the EU–Mercosur agreement, following the Parliament’s decision to refer it to the Court of Justice of the European Union.

title: EU can't replace Musk's Starlink yet, but is on right track, Kubilius tells Euronews
content: EU Defence Commissioner told Euronews the US remains irreplaceable for the bloc's security, specifically regarding space services. “When we have IRIS², it will be better than Starlink". But, the EU is not yet there.

title: France and Spain signal support to list Iran's Revolutionary Guard as terrorist group
content: Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps could soon be designated as a terrorist organisation in the European Union after France and Spain, the two key hold-outs, signalled a change of mind.

title: Danish MEP Dahl backs Rutte's view on EU defence dependence on US
content: The Danish EPP MEP said in an opinion article for Euronews that NATO secretary general is right to claim the EU remains dependent on the US for security, at least for now.

title: EU invests €650 million in cross-border hydrogen and electricity infrastructure projects
content: Spain is the EU member state receiving the most funding for cross-border electricity projects, while Germany is emerging as the frontrunner in hydrogen initiatives. Meanwhile, the European Commission is expected to launch its next call for proposals on energy infrastructure between April and June.

title: MEPs urge EU to block ICE from entering Europe for Winter Olympics
content: Several European lawmakers have urged the EU to impose restrictive measures on ICE, arguing that the agency should not operate in Europe due to concerns over democratic oversight and human rights.

title: 'It's better for Poland to stay with the złoty,' country’s finance minister says
content: Andrzej Domanski said that that keeping the złoty as the national currency gives the economy greater flexibility at a time of global uncertainty, despite ongoing debates over deeper eurozone integration.

title: Don’t shoot the messenger, Mark Rutte is right — for now
content: Europe lacks key military capabilities — especially independent command, intelligence, and digital infrastructure — most of which are still provided by the US, Danish MEP Henrik Dahl writes in an opinion article for Euronews.

title: India trade deal cements EU's voice in 'multipolar world', Costa tells Euronews
content: The European Council chief tells Euronews a free trade agreement with India will help stabilise a global economy rattled by tariffs. The deal will see duties reduced on more than 90% of EU exports.

title: China orchestrating 'dogfight' in space against EU assets, German minister says
content: It is possible Europe's adversaries are carrying already on activities to destablise the bloc's space assets in preparation for a future conflict, Jens Plötner also said.

title: Fact check: Will the Mercosur trade deal open the door to 'toxic' food in the EU?
content: From farmers burning tyres outside the European Parliament to motorway blockades across the continent, tensions around the EU-Mercosur trade agreement don't look set to go away. Many critics argue that it will lead to a flood of "toxic" products on the European market, but how true is this?

title: Shift in EU-US relations is 'structural, not temporary', Kaja Kallas warns
content: In the aftermath of the Greenland crisis, the EU's top diplomat has urged European nations to stop outsourcing their security and defence.

title: Watch the video: EU-India trade deal — what's inside?
content: The EU signed a historic trade deal with India on Tuesday. Why? Because with Trump in the White House and the European relations with Beijing being complicated, Brussels needs new friends. And it needs them fast.

title: International development aid: A burden or a soft power tool? Here's what Europeans think
content: Europeans are divided on whether development assistance is beneficial for the EU and on exactly how it should be spent.

title: Exclusive: EU-India deal shows 'reliable partners can work for good', Costa tells Euronews
content: In an exclusive interview with Euronews in New Delhi, European Council President António Costa hailed the EU-India trade pact as a major economic opportunity and strategic victory in an “uncertain world.”

title: Newsletter: Costa vouches for ‘cooperation over confrontation’ in an ‘uncertain world’
content: Also in this newsletter: Zelenskyy sets 2027 deadline for Ukraine's EU accession, and how France is emerging as the main holdout in push to blackslist Iran's Revolutionary Guard.

title: Can Europe catch up with AI? What is Brussels doing?
content: The AI Act positions Brussels as a global rule-maker, but adoption and investment in AI remain low. Can Europe close the gap with the US and China persist? Watch the video.

title: Europe Today: Exclusive interview with European Council President António Costa
content: Tune in to Euronews' new flagship morning programme, Europe Today, at 8 am Brussels time. In just 15 minutes, we bring you up to speed on the biggest news of the day.

title: Draghi to join EU leaders at retreat to boost competitiveness, Costa tells Euronews
content: Costa has held a series on informal meetings bringing together the 27 leaders to brainstorm without the formalities of a European summit.

title: EU lawmakers back declaration urging the bloc to lead in commercial fusion energy
content: MEPs from the European People's Party argued that fusion energy is a reality that needs to be explored and urged the EU executive to lay down a clear regulatory framework to attract investors.

title: Volodymyr Zelenskyy sets 2027 as target for Ukraine's EU accession date
content: According to an EU official speaking on condition of anonymity, Brussels is also floating the idea of 'gradual membership' to accelerate Ukraine's accession.

title: 'Time is of the essence' to build a made-in-Europe space policy, French and German ministers say
content: France is championing a preference European-made space assets related to defence, which some member states will probably be wary of given the need to rapidly ramp up the bloc's space capacity.

title: EU Commissioner Virkkunen urges US to respect EU digital rules
content: In a wide-ranging interview with Euronews, Henna Virkkunen, the EU Commissioner for Tech Sovereignty, speaks about the possibilities and pitfalls of AI, the investigation into X’s Grok chatbot and a possible social media ban for kids.

title: France emerges as key holdout in EU talks on blacklisting Iran’s Revolutionary Guard
content: Despite reports of mass casualties in Iran’s crackdown on recent protests, France remains wary of adding the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps to the bloc’s terror list, saying the step would achieve little given existing sanctions.

title: Watch the video: Should social media be banned for children?
content: France is officially at war with social media. And the battle cries are echoing all over Europe. President Emmanuel Macron say children's minds are "not for sale" and wants a social media ban for under-15s by September.

title: Working while studying: Which EU countries have the highest rates and why?
content: Working while studying is not the norm for most employees in the EU. However, financial necessity and career ambition may motivate some to do so.

title: Rutte faces backlash for telling Europeans to 'keep on dreaming' about independence from US security
content: NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte is under fire for his dismissive remarks about the idea of European separation from Washington's protection. "You can't, we can't," he said.

title: EU now has its own 'secure and encrypted' satellite communication system, Kubilius says
content: Eight satellites from five different member states are currently being pooled as part of GOVSATCOM. The Commission hopes this is the first step towards less dependence on the US - whose own communication systems are a lot more mature.

title: Did the pope really snub Emmanuel Macron over Notre-Dame's windows?
content: A clash over Notre Dame's windows and a proposed assisted-dying law are among the alleged reasons Pope Leo XIV did not want to see the French president.

title: EU Commission to probe Hungary's giant defence loan request over risk of misuse by Orbán
content: Hungary is the only member state whose EU payments are suspended because of systemic corruption risks, and the Commission now says any disbursement under the bloc's defence funding scheme would come with conditions.

title: Virkkunen warns X of ‘clear obligations’ amid EU investigation into Grok
content: The European Commission has opened a formal investigation into Grok, Elon Musk’s AI chatbot on X, over its use to generate non-consensual sexualised images of women and underage girls.

title: Newsletter: EU and India clinch ‘mother of all deals’
content: Also in this newsletter: the EU's tech chief speaks to Euronews, and Greenland's minerals minister weighs in on Trump's claims that a "framework" deal is in place for her Arctic country.

title: EU inks 'mother of all deals' with India trade agreement amid global turmoil
content: The EU Commission sealed a free-trade agreement with India on Tuesday, cutting tariffs on EU goods while leaving out sensitive sectors to appease Indian authorities. Europe’s carmakers will see tariffs gradually reduced under the agreement, hailed as the 'mother of all deals'.

title: Europe Today: EU Commission Executive Vice-President reacts to EU-India trade deal
content: Tune in to Euronews' new flagship morning programme, Europe Today, at 8 am Brussels time. In just 15 minutes, we bring you up to speed on the biggest news of the day.

title: AI power play: Can Europe catch up with the US and China?
content: The EU is leading the AI race with key policies like the AI Act - but the US and China are racing ahead with innovation and investment. Can the EU cover the gap and catch up?

title: World Economic Forum in Davos reflects global tensions, Harvard professor says
content: The World Economic Forum in Davos, which ended on Friday, once again revealed the profound international geopolitical transformations currently under way.

title: Commission approves eight more SAFE defence investment plans worth €74bn
content: SAFE is one of the biggest prongs of the EU's Readiness 2030 package, which aims to inject hundreds of billions of euros into defence before the end of the decade – by which time many intelligence agencies estimate Russia could attack another European country.

title: Mark Rutte defies MEPs and praises Donald Trump as 'very important' to NATO
content: The NATO Secretary General credited US President Donald Trump with pushing European allies to spend more money on defence.

title: EU energy ministers pledge to boost offshore wind power in North Sea
content: Nine European governments have agreed to expand offshore wind capacity across the North Sea to up to 100 GW by facilitating key cross-border projects. Ministers said the completion of these ambitions will cut electricity costs by 30% by 2040.

title: EU plans investment conference in Jordan in April
content: Commission President Ursula von der Leyen will visit Amman as the EU attempts to use economic diplomacy to foster prosperity in stable areas of the Middle East.

title: Greenlandic minister says US interests unclear with ‘no deal’ yet on the table
content: Minister Naaja Nathanielsen told Euronews that the Greenlandic government is seeking clarity on the Trump administration’s demands, cautioning that ‘full access’ to her Arctic country’s mineral resources would cross its red lines.

title: After bruising Greenland crisis, Europe shifts focus back to Ukraine
content: Ukraine is back at the top of the European agenda after Donald Trump's latest tariff threats briefly upended collective efforts towards peace.

title: Sabotage and misplaced funds: Misleading claims spread over Spain's train crashes
content: False online theories have filled an information gap as investigators work to discover what caused back-to-back deadly train collisions.

title: Europe's forests: Where are they growing fastest?
content: Portugal's forests are growing faster than those of any other country, but this surge comes at a massive environmental cost. How is the country trying to reverse course?

title: Exclusive: Trade Commissioner says ‘mother of all deals’ will open India market for EU companies
content: The European Union is pushing to open India’s economy to European companies as Brussels moves into the final stretch of negotiations on a long-awaited free-trade agreement with New Delhi, EU trade chief Maroš Šefčovič told Euronews.

title: Watch the video: Is the EU building a European army?
content: What if the EU assembled a European army? Well, the reality is... it probably won't. But we are forging something else.

title: 'Ukraine will be part of the discussion this week in India,' says Irish EU affairs minister
content: Thomas Byrne told Euronews' Europe Today morning show that "it's very, very important that we can put in place a trade agreement with India".

title: EU and AI: Is it a lost battle? Take our poll
content: Can the EU still catch up in the global race for artificial intelligence? And how far should the EU go to catch up? Take our poll and share your view.
